decision.title: Parliament Adopts 25 EU-Related Laws to Advance Accession Negotiations
decision.summary: Montenegro's Assembly adopted 25 laws on February 3, 2026, deemed necessary for EU accession negotiations, shortly after closing Chapter 32. The laws cover financial regulation, consumer protection, railway transport, pension funds, medicines, education, social housing, and organ transplantation. Minister Maida Gorčević emphasized this demonstrates Montenegro's commitment to closing all chapters by 2026. Sources: European Western Balkans, gov.me
decision.full_text:
On February 3, 2026, Montenegro's Parliament passed 25 laws necessary for the country's EU accession negotiations, occurring shortly after closing Chapter 32 at an Intergovernmental Conference.

Minister of European Affairs Maida Gorčević emphasized the significance, stating: 'Shortly after Intergovernmental Conference at which we closed Chapter 32, we once again demonstrated that we take seriously the opportunity to close all chapters by 2026.'

Legislative Areas Covered:
The adopted measures addressed financial regulation, including amendments to credit institution resolution laws and capital market legislation. Additional laws covered consumer protection, railway transport, pension funds, bonds, medicines, education, social housing, and organ transplantation procedures.

Significance:
The rapid passage of these priority laws demonstrates Montenegro's commitment to meeting EU benchmarks for negotiation chapters. Parliamentary sessions proceeded without extensive plenary debate on the individual legislation, reflecting their pre-established status as critical requirements for the accession process.
decision.title_mne: Skupstina usvojila 25 zakona vezanih za EU radi unaprjedjenja pristupnih pregovora
decision.summary_mne: Skupstina Crne Gore usvojila je 25 zakona 3. februara 2026. godine, koji se smatraju neophodnim za pristupne pregovore sa EU, ubrzo nakon zatvaranja Poglavlja 32. Zakoni pokrivaju finansijsku regulativu, zastitu potrosaca, zeljeznicki transport, penzione fondove, ljekove, obrazovanje, socijalno stanovanje i transplantaciju organa. Ministarka Maida Gorcevic istakla je da ovo pokazuje posvecjenost Crne Gore zatvaranju svih poglavlja do 2026. godine. Izvori: European Western Balkans, gov.me

assessments.summary: The adoption of 25 EU-related laws is a welcome signal of Montenegro's legislative momentum toward accession, but from the Ministry of Interior's perspective, this package is notably silent on the areas most critical to our mandate — Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security). The laws address financial regulation, consumer protection, transport, and social policy, none of which directly advance public safety, law enforcement reform, border management, or the fight against organized crime and corruption. While the political momentum is positive, the absence of interior-sector legislation in this high-priority batch raises concerns about whether the hardest benchmarks are being deferred.
assessments.executive_summary: This legislative package advances EU accession in areas outside the Ministry of Interior's core mandate. While politically significant, the complete absence of Chapter 23/24 legislation — covering police reform, organized crime, border management, and anti-corruption — suggests the most difficult accession benchmarks may be postponed. The Ministry recommends that the next legislative push prioritize interior-sector reforms with equal urgency.
assessments.reasoning:
The Ministry of Interior recognizes the strategic importance of adopting EU-aligned legislation to close negotiation chapters and maintain accession momentum. The closure of Chapter 32 (Financial Control) and the accompanying legislative package covering financial regulation, consumer protection, railway transport, pension funds, medicines, education, social housing, and organ transplantation all represent genuine progress.

However, from an interior-sector standpoint, this decision has limited direct relevance. The 25 adopted laws do not appear to address any of the core areas under the Ministry of Interior's competence: police reform and depoliticization, the legal framework for combating organized crime and corruption, border management and Schengen preparation, migration and asylum, cybersecurity, civil protection, or public administration reform within the security sector.

Chapters 23 and 24 remain the most scrutinized and difficult chapters in Montenegro's accession process. The European Commission's annual reports have consistently flagged insufficient progress on establishing a credible track record of investigations, prosecutions, and final convictions in organized crime and high-level corruption cases. The Uprava policije (Police Directorate) still faces questions about operational independence, inter-agency coordination, and intelligence-led policing capacity. Border management infrastructure, particularly at the crossings with Albania, Kosovo, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, requires significant investment to meet Schengen standards.

The procedural concern is also notable: these 25 laws were passed without extensive plenary debate, described as 'pre-established critical requirements.' While expedited adoption may be justified for technical harmonization laws in financial regulation or consumer protection, such an approach would be highly problematic if applied to interior-sector legislation. Laws governing police powers, surveillance, data protection, asylum procedures, or criminal procedure require robust parliamentary scrutiny, public consultation, and input from civil society and the Ombudsman's office. The precedent of fast-tracking legislation should not be extended to the sensitive domain of justice and home affairs.

The political framing — closing all chapters by 2026 — is ambitious and welcome, but it risks creating a perception that legislative quantity is being prioritized over implementation quality. The Ministry of Interior's experience with previous reforms (e.g., the 2021 Law on Internal Affairs, amendments to the Criminal Procedure Code) demonstrates that adoption alone does not guarantee operational impact. Without corresponding institutional capacity building, training, and resource allocation, new laws remain paper exercises.

Regional cooperation frameworks such as SELEC, PCC-SEE, and bilateral agreements with EU member states on police cooperation are not addressed in this package. Similarly, there is no mention of alignment with the EU's Directive on combating money laundering, the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) as it pertains to cybersecurity of critical infrastructure, or the revised EU Firearms Directive — all of which have interior-sector implications.

In summary, the decision is neither harmful nor particularly beneficial to the Ministry of Interior's mission. It is a neutral event that underscores the need for a comparable legislative push in the justice and home affairs domain.
key_concerns: Complete absence of Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and Chapter 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security) legislation in this high-profile legislative package

Risk that the fast-track adoption model — without extensive plenary debate — sets a precedent that could be inappropriately applied to sensitive interior-sector laws requiring robust parliamentary scrutiny
No progress on police reform, depoliticization of law enforcement, or strengthening the operational independence of the Police Directorate (Uprava policije)
Border management and Schengen preparation legislation remains unaddressed, despite the 2026 target creating time pressure
The political narrative of 'closing all chapters by 2026' may prioritize speed over implementation quality in the most difficult chapters
No legislation addressing organized crime enforcement frameworks, anti-corruption institutional capacity, or the track record requirement under Chapter 24
Migration and asylum legal framework harmonization with the EU acquis is not included, despite increasing transit migration pressure on the Western Balkans route
recommendations: Urgently prepare a dedicated legislative package for Chapters 23 and 24, with comparable political priority to the 25 laws just adopted, covering police reform, anti-corruption, organized crime, and judicial independence

Ensure that any interior-sector legislation undergoes full parliamentary debate, public consultation, and review by the Ombudsman — no fast-tracking of laws governing police powers, surveillance, or data protection

Accelerate preparation of a new Law on Border Control aligned with the Schengen Borders Code, including provisions for integrated border management (IBM) and interoperability with EU systems (SIS II, VIS, EES)
Submit to Parliament amendments to the Law on Internal Affairs that strengthen the operational independence of the Police Directorate and establish clear depoliticization safeguards
Develop a legislative roadmap for cybersecurity aligned with the NIS2 Directive and DORA, addressing critical infrastructure protection within the Ministry's competence
Invest in institutional capacity building alongside legislation — new laws require trained personnel, modern equipment, and inter-agency coordination protocols to produce real results
Engage with European Commission officials specifically on interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24 to ensure the 2026 closure target is grounded in substance, not only legislative output

counter_proposal.title: Parallel Chapter 23/24 Legislative Sprint
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Interior proposes that the government immediately launch a parallel legislative sprint specifically targeting Chapters 23 and 24, mirroring the urgency and political commitment demonstrated by this 25-law package. This sprint would include 10-15 priority laws and amendments covering police reform, organized crime prosecution frameworks, border management, migration and asylum, cybersecurity, and anti-corruption enforcement — all subject to proper parliamentary scrutiny and civil society consultation, unlike the expedited process used for the current package.
key_changes: Introduce a dedicated Chapter 23/24 legislative package within 60 days, with clear timelines and responsible institutions identified for each law
Prioritize amendments to the Law on Internal Affairs to guarantee Police Directorate independence and merit-based appointments
Draft a new Law on Border Control aligned with the Schengen Borders Code and submit for parliamentary review with a 90-day target
Prepare amendments to the Criminal Procedure Code strengthening special investigative measures for organized crime and high-level corruption
Mandate that all interior-sector legislation undergo a minimum 30-day public consultation period and Parliamentary Committee for Security and Defence review
Establish an inter-ministerial working group (Interior, Justice, European Affairs) to coordinate Chapter 23/24 legislative planning and avoid the siloed approach visible in the current package
expected_benefits: Demonstrates to the European Commission that Montenegro treats the hardest chapters with equal seriousness, strengthening the credibility of the 2026 closure target
Produces operationally meaningful laws — not just paper harmonization — by coupling legislative adoption with implementation plans and resource allocation
Builds public trust by subjecting sensitive security-sector laws to proper democratic scrutiny, distinguishing them from technical harmonization measures
Addresses the Commission's most persistent criticism: the gap between legislative adoption and real-world implementation in justice and home affairs
Positions Montenegro for Schengen candidacy by proactively aligning border management legislation with EU standards
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The Ministry of Interior has already identified the legislative gaps through its Chapter 24 action plan. Draft texts for several priority laws (border control, police reform amendments, cybersecurity) are in advanced stages of preparation. The main constraint is political will and parliamentary scheduling, both of which should be achievable given the demonstrated precedent of prioritizing EU-related legislation. The 60-90 day timeline is ambitious but realistic if inter-ministerial coordination is effectively managed.
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova predlaže da vlada odmah pokrene paralelni zakonodavni sprint koji je konkretno usmjeren na Poglavlja 23 i 24, odražavajući hitnost i političku posvećenost demonstriranu ovim paketom od 25 zakona. Ovaj sprint bi obuhvatio 10-15 prioritetnih zakona i amandmana koji pokrivaju reformu policije, okvire za krivično gonjenje organizovanog kriminala, upravljanje granicom, migracije i azil, sajber bezbjednost i sprovođenje antikorupcijskih mjera — sve podložno odgovarajućoj parlamentarnoj kontroli i konsultacijama sa civilnim društvom, za razliku od ubrzanog procesa korišćenog za trenutni paket.
key_changes_mne: Uvesti poseban zakonodavni paket za Poglavlja 23/24 u roku od 60 dana, sa jasnim rokovima i identifikovanim odgovornim institucijama za svaki zakon
Prioritetno tretirati amandmane na Zakon o unutrašnjim poslovima koji garantuju nezavisnost Uprave policije i imenovanja zasnovana na zaslugama
Izraditi novi Zakon o graničnoj kontroli usklađen sa Šengenskim graničnim kodeksom i podnijeti ga na parlamentarnu reviziju sa rokom od 90 dana
Pripremiti amandmane na Zakonik o krivičnom postupku koji jačaju posebne istražne mjere za organizovani kriminal i korupciju na visokom nivou
Obavezati da sve zakonodavstvo iz sektora unutrašnjih poslova prođe minimalni period javnih konsultacija od 30 dana i reviziju Odbora za bezbjednost i odbranu Skupštine

Uspostaviti međuministarsku radnu grupu (Unutrašnji poslovi, Pravda, Evropski poslovi) za koordinaciju zakonodavnog planiranja Poglavlja 23/24 i izbjegavanje izolovnog pristupa vidljivog u trenutnom paketu
expected_benefits_mne: Demonstrira Evropskoj komisiji da Crna Gora tretira najteža poglavlja sa jednakom ozbiljnošću, čime jača kredibilnost cilja zatvaranja do 2026.
Proizvodi operativno značajne zakone — ne samo usklađivanje na papiru — povezivanjem zakonodavnog usvajanja sa planovima implementacije i raspodjelom resursa
Gradi povjerenje javnosti podvrgavanjem osjetljivih zakona iz bezbjednosnog sektora odgovarajućoj demokratskoj kontroli, razlikujući ih od mjera tehničkog usklađivanja
Adresira najuporniju kritiku Komisije: jaz između zakonodavnog usvajanja i stvarne implementacije u oblasti pravde i unutrašnjih poslova
Pozicionira Crnu Goru za kandidaturu za Šengen proaktivnim usklađivanjem zakonodavstva o upravljanju granicom sa standardima EU
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova je već identifikovalo zakonodavne praznine kroz svoj akcioni plan za Poglavlje 24. Nacrti tekstova za nekoliko prioritetnih zakona (granična kontrola, amandmani na reformu policije, sajber bezbjednost) su u poodmakloj fazi pripreme. Glavno ograničenje je politička volja i parlamentarni raspored, koji bi oboje trebali biti ostvarivi s obzirom na demonstrirani presedan davanja prioriteta zakonodavstvu vezanom za EU. Rok od 60-90 dana je ambiciozan ali realističan ako se međuministarska koordinacija efikasno upravlja.

assessments.summary_mne: Usvajanje 25 zakona vezanih za EU je pozitivan signal zakonodavnog zamaha Crne Gore ka pristupanju, ali iz perspektive Ministarstva unutrasnjih poslova, ovaj paket je primjetno tihi po pitanju oblasti najkritičnijih za naš mandat — Poglavlja 23 (Pravosuđe i temeljna prava) i 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost). Zakoni se bave finansijskom regulacijom, zaštitom potrošača, transportom i socijalnom politikom, od čega ništa direktno ne unapređuje javnu bezbjednost, reformu organa za sprovođenje zakona, upravljanje granicom ili borbu protiv organizovanog kriminala i korupcije. Dok je politički zamah pozitivan, odsustvo zakonodavstva iz oblasti unutrašnjih poslova u ovom visoko-prioritetnom paketu izaziva zabrinutost da li se najteža mjerila odlažu.
key_concerns_mne: Potpuno odsustvo zakonodavstva iz Poglavlja 23 (Pravosuđe i temeljna prava) i Poglavlja 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost) u ovom istaknutom zakonodavnom paketu

Rizik da model ubrzanog usvajanja — bez opsežne plenarne debate — postavi presedan koji bi se mogao neprikladno primijeniti na osjetljive zakone iz oblasti unutrašnjih poslova koji zahtijevaju snažnu parlamentarnu kontrolu
Nema napretka u reformi policije, depolitizaciji organa za sprovođenje zakona ili jačanju operativne nezavisnosti Uprave policije
Zakonodavstvo o upravljanju granicom i pripremi za Šengen ostaje neadresirano, uprkos tome što rok 2026. stvara vremenski pritisak
Politički narativ o 'zatvaranju svih poglavlja do 2026.' može dati prednost brzini nad kvalitetom implementacije u najtežim poglavljima

Nema zakonodavstva koje se bavi okvirima za sprovođenje zakona u oblasti organizovanog kriminala, institucionalnim kapacitetima za borbu protiv korupcije ili zahtjevima za ostvarene rezultate u okviru Poglavlja 24
Usklađivanje pravnog okvira za migracije i azil sa pravnom tekovinom EU nije uključeno, uprkos rastućem pritisku tranzitne migracije na ruti Zapadnog Balkana
recommendations_mne: Hitno pripremiti poseban zakonodavni paket za Poglavlja 23 i 24, sa uporedivim političkim prioritetom kao 25 upravo usvojenih zakona, koji pokriva reformu policije, borbu protiv korupcije, organizovani kriminal i nezavisnost pravosuđa

Obezbijediti da svaki zakon iz oblasti unutrašnjih poslova prođe punu parlamentarnu debatu, javnu konsultaciju i reviziju od strane Zaštitnika ljudskih prava i sloboda — bez ubrzanog usvajanja zakona koji regulišu policijska ovlašćenja, nadzor ili zaštitu podataka

Ubrzati pripremu novog Zakona o graničnoj kontroli usklađenog sa Šengenskim graničnim kodeksom, uključujući odredbe o integrisanom upravljanju granicom (IBM) i interoperabilnosti sa sistemima EU (SIS II, VIS, EES)
Podnijeti Skupštini amandmane na Zakon o unutrašnjim poslovima koji jačaju operativnu nezavisnost Uprave policije i uspostavljaju jasne mjere zaštite od depolitizacije
Razviti zakonodavni plan za sajber bezbjednost usklađen sa NIS2 Direktivom i DORA, koji se bavi zaštitom kritične infrastrukture u nadležnosti Ministarstva

Investirati u izgradnju institucionalnih kapaciteta uporedo sa zakonodavstvom — novi zakoni zahtijevaju obučen kadar, modernu opremu i protokole za međuagencijsku koordinaciju da bi dali stvarne rezultate

Angažovati se sa zvaničnicima Evropske komisije konkretno po pitanju privremenih mjerila za Poglavlja 23 i 24 kako bi se osiguralo da je cilj zatvaranja do 2026. utemeljen na suštini, a ne samo na zakonodavnom učinku
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj zakonodavni paket unapređuje pristupanje EU u oblastima izvan osnovnog mandata Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova. Iako je politički značajan, potpuno odsustvo zakonodavstva iz Poglavlja 23/24 — koje pokriva reformu policije, organizovani kriminal, upravljanje granicom i borbu protiv korupcije — ukazuje na to da se najteža mjerila pristupanja možda odlažu. Ministarstvo preporučuje da sljedeći zakonodavni potez prioritetno tretira reforme u sektoru unutrašnjih poslova sa jednakom hitnošću.

assessments.summary: The adoption of 25 EU-related laws, including legislation on medicines and organ transplantation, represents a meaningful step toward aligning Montenegro's health legal framework with the EU acquis. However, the rushed parliamentary procedure—passing health-critical legislation without extensive plenary debate—raises serious concerns about the quality of transposition, implementation readiness, and whether Montenegro's healthcare system has the institutional capacity to enforce these new standards in practice.
assessments.executive_summary: This legislative package is a net positive for Montenegrin public health, advancing EU-standard regulation of medicines and organ transplantation. However, the Ministry of Health is concerned that speed was prioritized over substance: laws passed without adequate debate risk poor implementation, and Montenegro's healthcare system—already strained by workforce emigration and underfunding—may lack the capacity to meet the new standards without a dedicated implementation roadmap and additional resources.
assessments.reasoning:
From the Ministry of Health's perspective, this decision contains both significant opportunities and notable risks.

On the positive side, the adoption of laws on medicines and organ transplantation directly advances alignment with Chapter 28 (Consumer and Health Protection) of the EU acquis. Montenegro's pharmaceutical regulatory framework has historically lagged behind EU standards, particularly regarding market authorization procedures, pharmacovigilance, and pricing transparency. New legislation aligned with EU Directive 2001/83/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 would strengthen the Montenegrin Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (CInMED) and improve patient access to safe, quality-assured medicines. Similarly, organ transplantation legislation aligned with EU Directive 2010/53/EU on standards of quality and safety of human organs intended for transplantation is overdue. Montenegro's Clinical Center (KCCG) has limited transplant capacity, and a proper legal framework is a prerequisite for developing transplant programs and participating in European organ-sharing networks like Eurotransplant.

The consumer protection laws may also have indirect health benefits, particularly if they address food safety standards, product safety, and the regulation of health-related consumer goods—all areas where Montenegro needs to converge with EU norms.

However, the process raises serious concerns. The passage of 25 laws in a single parliamentary session without extensive plenary debate suggests these laws were fast-tracked. For health legislation, this is particularly problematic. Medicines law reform affects the entire pharmaceutical supply chain—from CInMED's capacity to conduct EU-standard market authorization reviews, to hospital pharmacies, to the RFZO (Health Insurance Fund) reimbursement list. Organ transplantation law requires not just legal text but an entire institutional infrastructure: donor registries, tissue typing laboratories, transplant coordination teams, and ethical oversight committees. Passing the law is perhaps 10% of the work.

Montenegro's healthcare system faces structural challenges that complicate implementation. The health workforce crisis is acute—an estimated 300-500 doctors have left Montenegro in recent years, many to EU member states (Germany, Slovenia, Croatia). The RFZO operates under chronic budget pressure, and the KCCG in Podgorica is the only tertiary facility for a population of roughly 620,000. New EU-aligned standards will require trained regulatory staff, clinical specialists, IT systems for pharmacovigilance reporting, and quality assurance infrastructure that does not currently exist at the required level.

The social housing and pension fund legislation in the package may also have indirect health implications. Adequate housing is a social determinant of health, and pension reform affects elderly healthcare access. However, without seeing the specific texts, the Ministry cannot assess whether these laws adequately consider health equity dimensions.

Finally, the political framing—emphasizing speed and chapter-closing rather than substantive reform—is a pattern the Ministry has observed before. Laws adopted primarily to satisfy EU benchmarks rather than to genuinely transform systems risk becoming 'paper compliance': legally transposed but practically unimplemented. Montenegro's track record on implementation of previously adopted health legislation (e.g., the 2016 Healthcare Law amendments) suggests this risk is not theoretical.
key_concerns: Health-critical legislation on medicines and organ transplantation was passed without extensive parliamentary debate, risking poorly scrutinized legal texts with implementation gaps
No publicly announced implementation roadmap, budget allocation, or capacity-building plan accompanies the new health laws
CInMED (Agency for Medicines) may lack the staffing and technical capacity to implement EU-standard pharmacovigilance and market authorization procedures immediately
Organ transplantation law requires institutional infrastructure (donor registries, transplant teams, tissue typing labs) that Montenegro does not currently possess at EU standards
Risk of 'paper compliance'—laws formally transposed to satisfy EU benchmarks but not operationally implemented in the healthcare system
The ongoing health workforce brain drain to EU countries undermines the capacity to implement any new health standards, regardless of legal framework quality
RFZO budget implications of aligning pharmaceutical reimbursement with EU standards have not been publicly addressed
Consumer protection provisions may not adequately cover health-specific dimensions (food safety, medical devices, e-health) without dedicated health input
recommendations: Publish the full texts of the adopted medicines and organ transplantation laws immediately and open a 90-day public consultation period for implementing bylaws and secondary legislation
Develop a detailed implementation roadmap for the medicines law with specific milestones, responsible institutions (CInMED, RFZO, KCCG), timelines, and budget requirements
Conduct a capacity assessment of CInMED to identify staffing, training, and IT infrastructure gaps relative to EU pharmacovigilance and market authorization requirements
Establish an inter-ministerial working group on organ transplantation implementation, including the Ministry of Health, KCCG, and international partners (e.g., Eurotransplant, Council of Europe EDQM)
Commission a fiscal impact assessment of pharmaceutical law alignment on the RFZO reimbursement budget, including projections for new medicine access and generic competition effects
Request EU technical assistance (TAIEX, Twinning) specifically for health law implementation, not just transposition
Ensure the next parliamentary session includes dedicated committee hearings on health legislation implementation progress

Link health workforce retention measures (salary increases, specialization funding, working condition improvements) to the new legal framework to prevent further brain drain that would make implementation impossible

counter_proposal.title: Health Law Implementation Guarantee Package
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than passing health legislation as part of a bulk package optimized for EU chapter-closing speed, the Ministry of Health would have advocated for a phased approach: adopt the laws now to meet EU benchmarks, but simultaneously table a binding Health Law Implementation Guarantee—a parliamentary resolution committing specific budget lines, institutional timelines, and accountability mechanisms to ensure the medicines and organ transplantation laws become operational realities, not just legal texts.
key_changes: Adopt a binding parliamentary resolution requiring the government to present a health law implementation plan within 60 days, with specific milestones for CInMED capacity building and transplant infrastructure
Earmark €2-3 million in the 2026 supplementary budget specifically for CInMED modernization (IT systems, staff training, EU network integration)
Establish a Health Law Implementation Monitoring Committee in Parliament with quarterly reporting obligations
Negotiate an EU pre-accession assistance (IPA III) project specifically for medicines regulation and organ transplantation system development
Include mandatory health workforce retention provisions (specialization scholarships, salary supplements) as a condition for transplant program development
expected_benefits: Prevents paper compliance by creating enforceable implementation obligations alongside legal transposition
Demonstrates to the EU that Montenegro is serious about operational alignment, not just legal harmonization—strengthening Chapter 28 closing arguments
Protects patient safety by ensuring regulatory capacity exists before new standards take legal effect
Creates a foundation for Montenegro's first sustainable organ transplant program, reducing costly patient transfers abroad
Strengthens CInMED's credibility as a regulatory authority, potentially enabling participation in EU mutual recognition procedures
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The laws are already adopted, so this counter-proposal does not require re-legislation. A parliamentary resolution and budget earmark are procedurally straightforward. EU technical assistance programs (TAIEX, Twinning, IPA III) are available and Montenegro is an eligible candidate. The main political challenge is competing budget priorities, but the amounts involved (€2-3M) are modest relative to the health budget and the cost of continued patient transfers abroad for transplantation and specialized care.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Paket garancija za implementaciju zdravstvenog zakonodavstva
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto usvajanja zdravstvenog zakonodavstva kao dijela masovnog paketa optimizovanog za brzinu zatvaranja poglavlja EU, Ministarstvo zdravlja bi se zalagalo za fazni pristup: usvojiti zakone sada radi ispunjavanja mjerila EU, ali istovremeno staviti na dnevni red obavezujuću Garanciju implementacije zdravstvenog zakonodavstva — parlamentarnu rezoluciju koja obavezuje na konkretne budžetske linije, institucionalne rokove i mehanizme odgovornosti kako bi se osiguralo da zakoni o ljekovima i transplantaciji organa postanu operativne realnosti, a ne samo zakonski tekstovi.
key_changes_mne: Usvojiti obavezujuću parlamentarnu rezoluciju koja zahtijeva od vlade da u roku od 60 dana predstavi plan implementacije zdravstvenog zakonodavstva, sa konkretnim prekretnicama za izgradnju kapaciteta CInMED-a i transplantacione infrastrukture
Izdvojiti 2-3 miliona eura u dopunskom budžetu za 2026. konkretno za modernizaciju CInMED-a (IT sistemi, obuka kadra, integracija u mreže EU)
Uspostaviti Parlamentarni odbor za praćenje implementacije zdravstvenog zakonodavstva sa obavezom kvartalnog izvještavanja
Pregovarati o projektu pretpristupne pomoći EU (IPA III) konkretno za regulaciju ljekova i razvoj sistema transplantacije organa
Uključiti obavezne odredbe o zadržavanju zdravstvenog kadra (stipendije za specijalizacije, dodaci na platu) kao uslov za razvoj transplantacionog programa
expected_benefits_mne: Sprečava usklađenost na papiru stvaranjem izvršivih obaveza implementacije uporedo sa zakonskom transpozicijom
Demonstrira EU da Crna Gora ozbiljno shvata operativno usklađivanje, a ne samo pravnu harmonizaciju — čime jača argumente za zatvaranje Poglavlja 28
Štiti bezbjednost pacijenata osiguravajući da regulatorni kapacitet postoji prije nego što novi standardi stupe na pravnu snagu
Stvara osnovu za prvi održivi program transplantacije organa u Crnoj Gori, smanjujući skupe transfere pacijenata u inostranstvo
Jača kredibilitet CInMED-a kao regulatornog tijela, potencijalno omogućavajući učešće u procedurama uzajamnog priznavanja EU
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Zakoni su već usvojeni, tako da ovaj protivprijedlog ne zahtijeva ponovno zakonodavstvo. Parlamentarna rezolucija i budžetsko izdvajanje su proceduralno jednostavni. Programi tehničke pomoći EU (TAIEX, Twinning, IPA III) su dostupni i Crna Gora je kvalifikovani kandidat. Glavni politički izazov su konkurentski budžetski prioriteti, ali iznosi u pitanju (2-3 miliona eura) su skromni u odnosu na zdravstveni budžet i troškove nastavka slanja pacijenata u inostranstvo na transplantaciju i specijalizovanu njegu.

assessments.summary_mne: Usvajanje 25 zakona vezanih za EU, uključujući zakonodavstvo o ljekovima i transplantaciji organa, predstavlja značajan korak ka usklađivanju zdravstvenog pravnog okvira Crne Gore sa pravnom tekovinom EU. Međutim, ubrzana parlamentarna procedura — usvajanje zdravstveno kritičnog zakonodavstva bez opsežne plenarne debate — izaziva ozbiljnu zabrinutost oko kvaliteta transpozicije, spremnosti za implementaciju i toga da li zdravstveni sistem Crne Gore ima institucionalnu sposobnost da u praksi sprovede ove nove standarde.
key_concerns_mne: Zdravstveno kritično zakonodavstvo o ljekovima i transplantaciji organa usvojeno je bez opsežne parlamentarne debate, što rizikuje loše kontrolisane zakonske tekstove sa prazninama u implementaciji
Nije javno objavljeno nikakav plan implementacije, budžetska alokacija niti plan za izgradnju kapaciteta koji prati nove zdravstvene zakone

Rizik od 'usklađenosti na papiru' — zakoni formalno transponovani da zadovolje mjerila EU, ali operativno neimplementirani u zdravstvenom sistemu
Tekući odliv zdravstvenog kadra u zemlje EU podriva kapacitet za implementaciju bilo kojih novih zdravstvenih standarda, bez obzira na kvalitet pravnog okvira
Budžetske implikacije za RFZO usklađivanja farmaceutske refundacije sa standardima EU nijesu javno adresirane
Odredbe o zaštiti potrošača možda ne pokrivaju adekvatno zdravstveno specifične dimenzije (bezbjednost hrane, medicinski uređaji, e-zdravlje) bez posebnog zdravstvenog doprinosa
recommendations_mne: Odmah objaviti pune tekstove usvojenih zakona o ljekovima i transplantaciji organa i otvoriti period javnih konsultacija od 90 dana za podzakonske akte i sekundarno zakonodavstvo
Razviti detaljan plan implementacije zakona o ljekovima sa konkretnim prekretnicama, odgovornim institucijama (CInMED, RFZO, KCCG), rokovima i budžetskim zahtjevima
Sprovesti procjenu kapaciteta CInMED-a radi identifikacije nedostataka u kadru, obukama i IT infrastrukturi u odnosu na zahtjeve EU za farmakovigilanciju i odobravanje stavljanja u promet
Uspostaviti međuministarsku radnu grupu za implementaciju transplantacije organa, uključujući Ministarstvo zdravlja, KCCG i međunarodne partnere (npr. Eurotransplant, Savjet Evrope EDQM)
Naručiti procjenu fiskalnog uticaja usklađivanja farmaceutskog zakonodavstva na budžet za refundaciju RFZO, uključujući projekcije za pristup novim ljekovima i efekte konkurencije generičkih ljekova
